title: About Me
desc: Hi! I'm Sam, and I'm a web developer! And a statistician! And a few other things, but mostly those first two.

I’m a self-motivated individual who specializes in building complete solutions to problems in web development and risk analysis. I prefer to work on many aspects of a project concurrently so that I can develop a better understanding of how each piece should fit together. My background in statistics necessitated learning coding tools in order to more effectively answer complex questions about the world. Since graduating, I’ve been focused on learning new ways to apply my skills in mathematics and code to a wide array of problems. I enjoy working with small teams of open-minded individuals with different ways of thinking -- being exposed to different viewpoints is a great way to diversify one’s approach to problems both inside and outside of a work environment. I’m looking forward to making a difference in the workplace by bringing my skills and talents.

title: Elbie
desc: Elbie (LB) is a bot I wrote to help run our sessions of Dungeon World, a rules-lite tabletop RPG in the vein of Dungeons and Dragons. As feature creep is wont to do, she quickly was found to need more than just dice rolling, and is now capable of tracking character statistics using a MongoDB database. We also thought it might be nice if she could play a character's theme song on command, for example, so now audio capabilities are being added.

Elbie is a passion project of mine, and I'm very proud of her -- not only does she function, but her entire architecture is built to be as extensible as possible, allowing people to write their own modules for her and easily include them. Her current incarnation is the third complete rewrite of her.

title: Tryp.Ninja
desc: For our final project in our Web Design Bootcamp, we designed a social-media-esque site called Tryp Ninja ("tryp" as in "tryptych", "ninja" as in "we own the domain tryp.ninja"). It allows users to curate "Stories" that are designed to be persistent, and can showcase events from as short as an afternoon to as long as a year. I have a timeline of my kitten's growth on there, for instance.

Tryp Ninja presented new challenges for us, and eventually involved working with Amazon S3 to host images, Google for login and basic user info, and Cloudinary for image distribution, on top of a React/Node.js framework. It was designed mobile-first, although the same actions are available on a computer as they are on a phone.

title: Societé
desc: Societé Apothecary is a small business in Portsmouth, New Hampshire specializing in herbal remedies and teas, run by a former classmate. At the time, she needed a way to manage both raw parts (used to make products) and retail products themselves, as well as a method to track suppliers, costs, and so on. Working with a small team, we created a system capable of posting to a database from a dashboard, and using that database to update Shopify as a POS system. Additionally, we set up webhooks so that upon fulfilling an order, the database could stay in sync with Shopify.
The dashboard is, unsuprisingly, not public, but as it is an open-source project, the code is visible on GitHub.
role: Authentication, back-end, API design, Shopify integration

title: React Memory Game
desc: This is a "game" built with React (using create-react-app for node.js) based on testing one's memory. There are 12 provided images (iconic albums from the 80s), and the goal is to click each one without repeating any of them. With each click, your score will update -- if it's a previously-unclicked album, it will increment by one. If you have previously clicked it, your score will return to 0. You can see your "best" score in the info bar as well.

A personal icon, James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem famously noted in "Losing My Edge" that the kids he sees "coming up from behind" in the music scene have "borrowed nostalgia for the unremembered 80s", which was such a damning indictment of my interests that it could have been written about me specfically.

title: Hermite Polynomials
desc: For my senior capstone project, I studied the Hermite polynomials, ostensibly to gain an insight into orthogonality as it could be applied to signal processing and wavelet theory. The Hermite functions are orthogonal over the whole real line with respect to an exponential weighting function. As I worked with them, I found that they could be used to approximate any continuous function function on the real line, using a similar approach that one would take to derive a Fourier series.

More work on the project showed that there was a previously-undiscovered relationship between the coefficient of the Hermite polynomial of degree n and the degree-n derivative of the function, which allowed a method of calculating Hermite coefficients that actually did not use the Hermite polynomials in any way, and allowed us to construct efficient, powerful approximations of continuous and continuously-differentiable functions that were better (from a sum-squared error perspective) than a Taylor series over a given interval.
I presented this research at the undergraduate conference Ithaca College holds every year, the Whalen Seminar, and won the award for Mathematics that year, which was a huge honor!

title: Higher-Dimension Polyhedra
desc: In my sophomore year, I developed a formula for determining the value of an n-dimensional figurate number corresponding to certain categories of pyramidal numbers.

Since, for example, the triangular numbers (1,3,6,10,...) are formed by summing the natural numbers and the tetrahedral numbers (triangular pyramid) are formed by summing the triangular numbers, we can extend this approach to both pyramidal number with an arbitrary amount of sides (11, for example) and pyramids in arbitrarily high dimensions (11, for example).

What was pleasantly notable about this project was the fact that the formula made use of a relation I had developed freshman year involving Pascal's Triangle and arbitrary "seeds" for it. That allowed me to use a combinatoric approach to prove my new formula!

title: Golden Ratios beyond ϕ
desc: Throughout my college career, I had dallied in trying to solve the problem of golden ratios in m-bonacci sequences. In the classical Fibonacci series, one sums the two previous terms to get the next term, and the ratio between successive terms approaches approximately 1.618. If one instead sums the previous three terms, the ratio between successive terms approaches roughly 1.8393. What I wondered was if there was a good way to derive that value directly from the number of terms.

I made a lot of progress on answering that question, and from my latest work, the answer appears to be "no". However, I was able to note some interesting relations and discover an equation for the inverse, which given the ratio tells you the number of terms, a less exciting relation.

title: Recreating Density Functions
desc: Using techniques from statistics and best-fit analysis, combined with what I had learned about probability distributions, I began developing a technique to recreate probability distributions from a list of their moments. Motivating this research were questions like "what does a distribution have kurtosis 4 look like versus kurtosis 10?" and "what distribution could have generated this data?" These techniques are fairly specialized and work best on certain families of distributions, but they use essentially the same theory behind fitting polynomials to data, just applied in novel ways.

title: The Cavalcade of Sin
desc: The Cavalcade of Sin (formerly Sam Lloyd & The Cavalcade of Sin, before it grew to include more members than just me) was/is the name I worked under when making and performing music for several years. This photo was taken during one of our shows at The Nines, in Ithaca. We fancied ourselves a sort of goth disco revival, which, despite the fact that we played a mean synthesizer and often appeared in a cloud of glitter, meant that the college crowd didn't really "get" us. But it was still a good time.

Since the amiable separation of the band (two to three to four people, depending on who, how, and when you're counting), I have continued making music, but have been somewhat reticent to continue using the Cavalcade's name, for both personal and historical reasons. Despite our separation, I do keep my gold-studded shirt pressed and ready in case some sort of goth-disco emergency necessitated our reappearance.

title: Salvage OST
desc: "Salvage" was a game designed by some friends of ours, who conceived of a game set in space, about an astronaut struggling to find the materials needed to repair his ship after a deadly raid by space pirates. They asked me if I would be willing to provide music and sound design. Although the game did eventually come to fruition, it never really manifested in the ways the designers were hoping for. Despite this, the soundtrack did entirely get made, and it remains something I'm proud of.

The process of making the soundtrack let me explore sounds and textures in a way I hadn't previously allowed myself the freedom to do. The challenge of conveying the feel of a level by scoring it was a new one for me, and there are a few touches I'm particularly proud of -- the closing theme is the opening theme with added instrumentation and percussion, for example, and the drum sequencing was borrowed from another project of mine one of the designers particularly admired (a seven-minute ambient disco version of Bruce Springsteen's "I'm on Fire" (yes.))
I have also contributed music to a film currently in production whose release is anticipated to release in 2019, set in a near-future cyberpunk arcade.

title: Landon House Brewing
desc: In my ever-decreasing amount of spare time, I also homebrew beers, ciders, and meads! And what's more is they're actually pretty good!

This particular image is a logo I made for our beer "2udy" (pronounced "two-dee"), a spiritual successor to our first beer, though made with a recipe we promptly lost and ingredients that we managed to lose the labels for immediately afterward, making this mysteriously tasty brew impossible to replicate. The design, of course, comes from the iconic post for "Plan 9 From Outer Space", although I am now reasonably certain that all of our materials were terrestrial.
